Hi Sebastian,

It was a while ago so I don't remember which experiments I t=
ried, but I
seem to remember having trouble evolving solutions for even ver=
y simple
feed-forward input output mappings (again, I don't remember specif=
ic
details). I checked and re-checked the output of every stage of my
imple=
mentation of ES-HN (and consulted you to clarify some aspects of your
imple=
mentation) but something somewhere must have been incorrect. I'm
wondering =
now if the problem wasn't with the ES-HN implementation but
rather that it =
brought out an issue with some other part of AHNI. I
recently fixed a bug i=
n how non-layered feed-forward networks are executed
so perhaps ES-HN was t=
riggering this issue. If I do some more testing I'll
let you know the resul=
ts.

Cheers,
Oliver


T: 0421 972 953 | E: oliver.coleman@... | W: ht=
tp://ojcoleman.com

>
>
> Hi Oliver,
>
> Ye=
s, it's great to have cluster functionality in there!
>
> Can you elaborate=
 a little bit on what exactly didn't work when you tried
> to run your expe=
riments with ES-HyperNEAT? Other people might run into the
> same
> problem=
s so trying to figure out exactly what the problem was could be
> helpful.
=
>
> Did you ever try to implement the simple maze navigation task from the
=
> same paper?
>
> Best,
> Sebastian
>

iver Coleman oliver.coleman@...

every aspect of the ES-HyperNEAT

ble to reproduce the experiments in
>> Risi S. and Stanley K.O. (2012) An E=
nhanced Hypercube-Based Encoding for
>> Evolving the Placement, Density and=

>> Life, MIT Press, thus the implement=
ation should be assumed to be be not
>> working. Feel free to try it out an=
d let me know how you go! :)

euroevolution is likely
>>> to benefit from massive and increasing computat=
ional power, so it's good if
>>> our software can take advantage of it.
>>>=

>>> By the way, I see notes in your github for support of all kinds of
>>>=
 variants as well, such as ES-HyperNEAT, LEO, NSGA-II, and novelty search.
=
>>> Are all those really working well and validated?  If so I'd add mention=
 of
>>> them to my software links collection (
>>> http://www.cs.ucf.edu/~k=
stanley/#software).  I'm also planning to

's become so large and disorganized that new
>>> people coming in can't fig=
ure out which package they should really be
>>> choosing.  My plan is to ma=
ke it a lot more helpful in pointing people to

way AHNI deserves to be featured prominently.

orward networks are executed so perhaps ES-HN was triggering this issue. If=

      <p>Hi Oliver, thanks fo=
r your work on AHNI, cluster compatibility is very useful.=C2=A0 As with ot=
her areas of machine learning, neuroevolution is likely to benefit from mas=
sive and increasing computational power, so it's good if our software c=
an take advantage of it.=C2=A0 <br><br>By the way, I see notes in your gith=
ub for support of all kinds of variants as well, such as ES-HyperNEAT, LEO,=
 NSGA-II, and novelty search.=C2=A0 Are all those really working well and v=
alidated?=C2=A0 If so I'd add mention of them to my software links coll=
ection (<a href=3D"http://www.cs.ucf.edu/~kstanley/#software" target=3D"_bl=
ank">http://www.cs.ucf.edu/~kstanley/#software</a>).=C2=A0 I'm also pla=
nning to overhaul that list because it's become so large and disorganiz=
ed that new people coming in can't figure out which package they should=
 really be choosing.=C2=A0 My plan is to make it a lot more helpful in poin=
ting people to what they need.=C2=A0 But anyway AHNI deserves to be feature=
d prominently.<br><br>Best,<br><br>ken=C2=A0</p>

    </div>
